user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketGetInfo(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_socket_prop_t *sock_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sock_prop);

    memset(sock_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_socket_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        strncpy(sock_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(sock_prop->name) - 1);
        sock_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code        = OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl(&token, sock_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME]; /**< @brief Name of the socket */
    osal_id_t creator;               /**< @brief OSAL TaskID which opened the socket */
} OS_socket_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_socket_prop_t *sock_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_stream_table
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed were examined and judged not suspicious for Rule 8.13: - The parameter sock_prop in OS_SocketGetInfo is written (memset and strncpy) so it must be a non-const pointer. - The token variable is populated by OS_ObjectIdGetById (which writes token->obj_idx/obj_id) so the token object cannot be declared const in that context. - OS_ObjectIdGetById itself writes into the token (calls OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex and assigns token->obj_id), so its token parameter appropriately lacks const. - OS_SocketGetInfo_Impl already declares its token parameter as const, so it complies with the rule. - The destination argument of strncpy must be a writable (non-const) pointer. - The inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken already takes a const OS_object_token_t * (no issue). The listed fragments are the locations where non-const pointers to objects that appear to be only read from (or where the const-qualification of the pointed-to type should be checked) appear and therefore warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
